sp.p: How cruel is a Father, to make the Life he gave so miserable, as mine must be!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Mistress, we are all undone, I peept into my Master's Closet, and there's the Bumkin Knight and he, Signing and Sealing, and that Ink-Bottle Rascal, busie in diverting the Papers.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: This is worst of all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am lost beyond Redemption, there's no avoiding this ruin, unless fair Lucy will fly with me, and in my Fortune find shelter from this storm.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Alas, I dare not! I cannot fly from that which Heaven makes my Duty.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Bellville, there's a Gentleman without, come Post from the Country, who desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let him come in—

lg.l: What shou'd this be?

sp.stage: Enter Elliot, Servant to Mr. Bellville ' s Uncle.
sp.p: How! Elliot— what News with you?

sp.speaker: Elli.
sp.p: Very sad, Sir, at least to me, your Uncle my good Master is dead, and has left all his Estate to you, Real and Personal: 〈◊〉 ●… Letter from his Steward, Mr. Trusty, who keeps all things in qulet Possession for you, and desires you to hasten down with all the speed you can.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis so— My Uncle was lately in good Health.

sp.speaker: Elli.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but died suddenly of an Appoplex, I lost a good Master.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And you have found another, if you please, Elliot.

sp.speaker: Elli.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, what order do you please to take for going?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: D'ye know my Lodging, Elliot?

sp.speaker: Elli.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I was directed from thence to find you here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go thither then, and refresh your self, I believe you have Rid hard, I have some 〈◊〉 that I must look after; but I'le come thither with all the speed I can, and then order every thing.

sp.speaker: Elli.
sp.p: I'le wait there for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: This is very unlucky, wou'd this News had come a little sooner, this Argument wou'd Convert the Old Gentleman to the Religion of our side.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But I fear 'tis gone too far.
'Twill turn him again, and fet him, like a wind mill, to ●…all with the wind that changes, and turn off the Knight, as he did the Squire.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But if he has Sign'd Covenants, he'll never venture the battle of a Suit of Law, he dreads a Writ, as he wou'd a piece of Canon 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 him.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: 'Slife, how dull we are; yet if we cou'd make him of our Party, there might be some contrivance to 〈◊〉 this Knight 〈◊〉 upon a wrong Adventure.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: 'Tis possible this additional Consideration might incline his 〈◊〉 Prudence, but I fear 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Mistress, I have a Fancy come into my Head, that may do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee Phill, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a very pretty one, and tends to no less than to make my self a Lady.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: On my Life, I have hit on the same fancy with Phill.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Mine is to pack the Cards upon him, and shuffle me to turn up instead of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Say no more, Phill, I have it all; thou art the Father, and I the Mother of this Plot; let me alone to shape it, now thou hast got it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But dear Cousin Feewell, what is't.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Say no more, but let me alone with my Cousin Landy, you ●…ellville shall be Taught your Part in good time, and you Cousin Lucy have nothing to say, but to have and to hold, after the Parson.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You intend, I suppose, to draw my Old Master into the Plot. It cannot fail; he will certainly take the Bait, and then Mistress, I must take place of you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Phill; thou dost deserve it for taking mine.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p:
Come, no Words, nor Conjuring up Doubts, withdraw all, and leave me to Assault this Castle of Treasure, which is unfortified to hold out against such Batteries as I shall raise against him, observe well your Parts. One thing I had forgot; you Bellville, you must seem a little cold,
as if your new Fortune, and being so ill us'd by him had chill'd your passion for his Daughter; stay, give me the Letter, now be gone, while I wait for his bolting out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Heaven prosper your attempt.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: They are gone in time, see where the Squadron comes, led by Captain Scrible, having, I suppose, newly Sign'd the Treaty.
sp.stage: Enter Scrible first, Landy, and Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Scrible.
sp.p: Give you joy, Mr. Landy, and you, Sir Timothy; I suppose you have no business more for me at present, I must hasten and provide other Matters necessary for the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Do, good Mr. Scrible.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, I must about Matters too, in good faith; 〈◊〉 ●…mble the Parson, time, and place together, I long y faith to make Mrs. Lucy the Lady Shallow, and Ise return quickly.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: The sooner the welcomer, good Son, as I think I may now call you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And I hope I may call you Father, and get a little Son to make you a great Father.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Lustily spoke y faith, Sir Timothy, and I'll give it a Father's Blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And in gud faith Ise hasten to get it, so farewell 'till then; Ise quickly come to fetch my Lady, to encrease the Family of the Shallowe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: So, all goes well. Pretty y faith! they would have perswaded me to take Ninepence for a Noble; very pretty y faith. O 〈◊〉 Feewell, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I waited to speak with you, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What, about the old Story? Pray Cousin Feeweell give off the pursuit of that Matter, 'tis a cold scent, and I am engag'd, fully engag'd.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir, for 'tis a new Matter I have to acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: New Matter, pish, what new Matter! my Daughter's my Daughter, and my Care of her the same▪ and a Thousand a year is but a Thousand a year, and two Thousand is two Thousand; and I must desire Mr. Bellville to forbear further troubling himself, and me.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I wish, Sir, ne may not too readily comply; he had your Promise, and I assure you, resents his injury.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I think I did utter a hasty word, or so, but two Thousand a year is a very good Excuse:

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: But almost three Thousand is a better Argument.
In short, Sir, I resolv'd, without Mr. Bellvill's leave, to acquaint you that his Uncle is dead, and has left him above Fifteen Hundred a year, besides a great Personal Estate.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: How, Cousin, sure this is a devise?
Read this Letter, and if your Opinion holds, you will repent what you now joy in.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: By my life 'tis so indeed; nay, I have heard his Unkle had such a fair Estate. O Mr. Feewell, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I hope nothing but what may be undone.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: O yes, Cousin, that scrible scrable Rascal has fetter'd me in Articles, to get his Fee.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Not so fast, I hope, but that you may get loose.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: O impossible, they'll clap Writs upon me, and toss me into the Spiritual Court, where no flesh ever 'scap'd destruction.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I am very much troubled, is there no Remedy?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: O I would there were, Cousin, you know I ever esteem'd Mr. Bellvill's Person.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I must confess I wonder'd you were so suddenly fond of this Knight, of the ill-favour'd Countenance; besides, you knew your Daughter lov'd Bellville, some Consideration should have been had of her Content.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Alas! 'twas for her sake; care of her, care of her; 'tis very unfortunate, had this News come but a day sooner.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: That's not to be helpt now, if I were you, I'de stand the 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: No, Cousin, I'de as willingly Death should Arrest me as a Serjeant, and had as good almost fall into the hands of the Hangman, as the Lawyers; besides publick shame, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Wou'd you be truly and heartily pleas'd, if a way might be found to set you safely free, and Bellville 〈◊〉 have your Daughter?
Cousin, Cousin, with all my Soul, I have found this Knight to be Sir Shallow, indeed a very Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: And will you steadily act in the 〈◊〉, if a handsome one be contriv'd?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Most chearfully, Cousin, trust me, most willingl with my best skill and power. But d'ye hear, Cousin, will not this great addition of Fortune, joyn'd to the unhappy usage of Mr. Bellville, make him flye off?

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: 'Troth he is something grumb upon the Matter, but 'tis possible his love for your Daughter may overcome.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Perswade him, good Cousin, work him into easiness, and forgiveness; I always esteem'd his Person, desire him to believe it from a penitent and hasty Father; good Cousin can you tell where we may find him?

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Easily, Sir, for I left him taking his leave of his Mistress, I saw her begin to put finger in eye.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Then I fear he'll fall off. Call 'em in, good Cousin, and assist me in that you say is your own design; call 'em in, good Cousin, and indeavour to soften him by the way; tell the Girl I charge her to look kindly 〈◊〉 him.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll try my utmost—
But be sure, Sir, to be very kind to him.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Doubt it not in the least. Now am I to go to Sentence and Repentance, and my Pennance will be (no doubt on't) an additional Portion; how this Earthquake of Land has shaken me? No matter, if the Plot be well laid, and succeeds, I shall be contented, and my poor Girl will be pleas'd. And I consider, when Riches give me leave, that the truth on't is, this Knight is a very Coxcomb, and my Daughter had been as well dispos'd of in a deep Well, as to this Shallow; what Troubles have I twisted my self into! O these Girls, these Girls, every one of them gives as much trouble as a Leash of Boys, they must be rear'd like Orange Trees in a cold Country, kept within doors, and carefully hous'd; what a happiness it would be for Parents, were there an Insurance-Office for getting Boys instead of Girls, any Wise Man wou'd give Ten in the Hundred to have his Wife Insur'd. Soft, they come— I see my Cousin Feewell is working the Matter.
sp.stage: Enter Feewell, earnestly whispering with Bellville, Lucy and her Maid following.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have you any Commands for me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I wish Mr. Bellville I had the power to Command you, but I am now the Petitioner for what you once desir'd.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I do not understand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I think you once desir'd Lucy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I desire you should have her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Once indeed, Sir, you seem'd to be of that mind, but presently I was forbid to hope that happiness.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I was too hasty I confess, and if you still love my Daughter, she shall plead my excuse. Speak to him, huzzy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What shou'd I say, Sir?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What shou'd I say! when I scrupled at your having Mr. Bellville; then you cou'd interrupt me with your chattering, and now forsooth, you can't speak; look kindly on him, and win him into kindness and forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You hear, Mr. Bellville, what my Father says, if you love me still.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Well said, my best Girl, y faith, that was a devilish look; can you resist it, Mr. Bellville?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I must ever love Mrs. Lucy, I dare not deny that powerful truth; but to what purpose is all this discourse? I hear you are engag'd to Knight-hood.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Then let me speak, I have promis'd my Cousin Landy to find a way to free him from that engagement; he joyfully consents to act his part in the Plot, and if you love Mrs. Lucy still; she shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: With an addition of Portion, Mr. Feewell, to express my esteem of you.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Come, 〈◊〉, Mrs. Lucy shall be yours; but no more words, we'll in, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 our Design, which I think cannot fail; Phill is one of the Party, Sir.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: She's honest, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: ●…il.
sp.p: At this time especially, when my own advantage Rewards me for it.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: You must be sure, Madam Phil. that must be, under pretence of Modesty, to so order and muffle your self with Hoods, that the Knight may not discover.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Trust that to my management.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Mrs. Lucy, when the Knight comes next to make his last Claim, you must manage your Hoods so as to be a pattern for Phil. But now let's withdraw, and perfect 〈◊〉 Design.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Well, I must rid my self of these Lodgers, for as long as they domineer, at this rate, I shall never be Master of my own House, or my Wife; at the end of this 〈◊〉 I shall 〈◊〉 old Landy to remove himself, his Daughter, and the rest of his Luggage; as long as they are here, this Feewell will have a 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 upon my House, under pretence 〈◊〉 coming to 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 Landy. Besides, wherever a Rich young Heiress lives, all the young 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 and starch'd 〈◊〉 of the Town, come buzzing about that House all day long, like so many Bees about a Hive, and the Servants need have no other business, than to open the door to Penny-Post Men, and 〈◊〉 in the shape of Porters.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Who dost thou 〈◊〉 gave this 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 to thee?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, it was given me by a Woman in haste, just at the turning of the last Street.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 you so! This is Feewell, I know the voice. I'll venture to draw nearer, and observe him a little; 'tis late in the Evening, and 〈◊〉 not easily discover me.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: At the Corner of the 〈◊〉 Street! 〈◊〉 thou so? I have a strong guess, before I open it, from whence it comes.

sp.speaker: Lurch
sp.p: So have I, I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Few.
sp.p: Yes, it is that Dear Creature, Lurch his Wife, as I imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis that dear Devil, as I imagin'd too.

p.hi: Sir, To Morrow at Three of the Clock in the Afternoon, my Husband goes Abroad, to Accompany the Corps of a deceased Friend; this is to let you know, I expect your Company in my 〈◊〉 at that 〈◊〉, begging that you wou'd not omit so blessed an Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: To make me a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Feewell
sp.p: I shall impatiently wait you at the Place appointed, 〈◊〉 without Seconds; if you are a Man of Honour do not fail me, who am yours, &c.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: No Seconds, said she? tho, by her leave, I intend to make a third, to hinder the effusion of Christian Blood.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Yes, fair Inviter, I will meet thee.

O thou dear expected Hour of Three in the Afternoon to Morrow, how long wilt thou 〈◊〉 coming? How shall I be able to pass my time away with Patience? To Night I'le go in search of Bellwille, or pick up some other intimate Acquaintance, with whom I may be free, and over a Glass of Life-giving Liquor, I'le heighten Humour, and Enjoy my Friend.
To Morrow for my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Your Mistress, and my Wife— Hence forward I shall never wonder at these Billet-douxs, for being made up in the fashion of Horns— Blessed Opportunity, and Man of Honour— O sine Age!
O dainty fine Age! O delicious Age!
What a Wife of defiance have I got?

O Husbands, Husbands, you that are fast in the Lobs-Pound of Matrimony, behold, and pity your Poor Fellow sufferer: Was it not sufficient that we entred the Prison voluntarily but we must bind our selves over to such good Behaviour, and give such swinging Security for our staying there? We have all paid dearly for our Peeping and 〈◊〉.

lg.l: So have I seen a Mouse with Hunger spent,
To the strong Parmazans inviting scent
Advance, and creep around the wiery Gin,
That seems to fortifie the Bait within▪
At length (for nothing hazzard, nothing hold,
Hunger and Women make a Coward bold)
The thoughtless Animal, resolv'd to dare,
Ventures within the Matrimonial Snare:
Down falls the Trap door of the teacherous House,
And makes a Husband of that Captive Mouse.

div.head: A Night Scene.
div.stage: Enter Sir John 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 his Night Gown, and a dark Lanthorn in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I Am got loose from her Ladyship at last! Never was Poor Man so put to it, to play the Lover with his own Wife! One such another Night, wou'd have forc'd me to have cross'd the Cudgels, and confess'd the Husband in my own defence.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Sir John, Sir John, is it you?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis I, all that's left of me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I heard your Worship come out of my Lady's Chamber; I hav'n't Slept a wink all this Night, for fear my Lady should have discover'd you, and I was terribly afraid she had, because I heard her make a Noise, and cry out, as I thought— just when your Worship left her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thou are in the right, the Out-cry was made by my Wife, but not because she discover'd me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Why was it then?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Twas because I 〈◊〉 her a 〈◊〉 sort of a 〈◊〉 at my parting, instead of a more civil good Morrow, she might reasonably have expected from me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend your meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be more 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, I have 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 Marks of Remembrance behind me, on her Ladyship's Face, with these Ten Executioners, that the Doctor will not be able 〈◊〉 Cure them this Month, with all his Art; in short, I Counterfeited the Madman all 〈◊〉 sudden, rose from her Bed in a Clap of 〈◊〉, like 〈◊〉 from his Mistress, and have left such a storm of my Fingers ends on her Visage, that she writes no more Love-Letters in haste, I 〈◊〉 〈◊〉. But d'you hear; Go you up to your Lady immediately, and strive to 〈◊〉 her as well as you can, and above all, be sure you tell her, you have 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 the Doctor is given to be Lunatick 〈◊〉 certain 〈◊〉. Go get you gone, you'll find I have lock'd the door upon her. In the mean time, I'll dress my self abroad in my Riding Habit, in order to return home again, as from the Country. Do as I bid you, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, I will go to her, 〈◊〉 you have Commanded me, tho' I tremble at the approaching storm.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: (alone)

lg.l: This it is to have a Matrimonial Conduct.
Happy were all the Husbands in the Nation,
Could they, like me, put down th' old Horning Fashion,
And follow this new Dance, as I have led it,
Of Cuckolding themselves to save their Credit.

sp.p: Yes, Sir John, I am upon my guard, being near the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What Enemy, Mr. Lurch, I see none but your Wife?

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Why that's one, the other is enclos'd here in this Fortification; but I shall storm it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Lurch, your 〈◊〉 makes you fancy it.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p:
Sir John, I never saw a Marriage in all my life, but a Cuckold-Maker belong'd to it; every Husband is as sure of his evil Genius, as having a shadow when the Sun shines on him. A Cuckold-Maker is as
inseparate from our Calling, as an Apothecary from a Doctor of Physick he Prescribes, but the Apothecary Administors.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Lurch, you grow Extravagant.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Let her give me the Key then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: There are Womens things in it, not fit to be seen.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: I believe so, truly; now Sir John, do you perceive, Sir John▪ look you Mrs. no more delays, if you'll not open the door, I'll fire upon the Castle.
sp.stage: Offers his Blunderbuss at the Chést.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; here Betty, give him the Key.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There 'tis, Sir, now for your Discovery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: So, have you found this mighty Enemy▪

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Lurch, this is so unreasonable, are you not asham'd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Lurch.
sp.p: I had ears sure— this is odd, very odd.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Lurch, come ask your Wife forgiveness, and use her more like a reasonable Man.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Why, I confess I did believe she had made me a Beast; come, Sweet heart, we'll forget, and forgive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: And how long will you continue reasonable?

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: As long as you please to let me; come, my Dear, no more skirmishing, Peace is concluded, and I'll present thee with a handsome New Gown, and the Appurtenances, as a Testimony of my Reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well said, Mr. Lurch, and now prepare for Mirth and Jollity; we shall be presently Invited to Mrs. Lucy's Wedding, and Mr. Landy has prepar'd a mighty Feast.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: Send him a happy Voyage through the uncertain ways of Matrimony.

lg.l: Constant severeness that warm Sex inflames,
The wildest Haggards gentle Manning tames:
Too much ill usage, and to want all trust
Raises Revenge, to make their Crimes seem just.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: THere lies my Lady in the next Room, Railing at, and Cursing the Doctor, and Swearing she'll tear him to pieces if he durst come near her, and it cannot be long before he must come.

O Doctor! you are Born under a Lucky Planet, you are the happiest Man;
my Lady thinks it an Age till she sees you! But we must speak softly, she's run half Mad for you; well, 'tis most certain, you are a most taking Man with the Ladies; and you know mine in particular, has alwaies had an Esteem for your Person, she does nothing but sigh all day for you, I believe poor Lady she'll run Mad; but you must be secret, or you ruin all, you know there's a Husband in the case.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Poor Lady, she needs not fear, I took an Oath to be secret, when I was Sworn Doctor: Alas! she is not the first Lady who has fallen in love with my Person, one half of my Women Patients are in her Condition.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I must inform you, that my Lady has had the Misfortune to hurt her self a little with a fall, as you'll see by her Face, and has taken that occasion to feign her self 〈◊〉 for your sake, has sent her own Husband to fetch you, and lies on her Bed in the next Chamber, expecting your happy Arrival; I blush to say more, but you may guess the rest.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: What her Ladyship has a violent sit of the Vapours, I warrant, is it not? Well, let me alone with her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: But hold, do you Entertain your self in this Room; while I acquaint her that you are come, as I am order'd: If the violence of her Passion should cause her to be extravagant in her Actions, you are not to be surpris'd, now I have told you how excessively she loves you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Never fear, I can be as Extravagant as she is; I like an open bare-fac'd Love that confesses it self; the more manifest the Disease is, the more easily the Remedy is applied.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Expect here a Moment then, and you shall be admitted immediately, I must use you now like a Lover, and not like a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Doctor or Lover, Lover or Doctor, Student in Physick, or Student in Love, are Synonimous. We Doctors of Physick, have a large Cure of Bodies, an unlimited Prerogative over Flesh and Blood.
But here's my Patient! Hem! Hem! Now to show my skill in manageing an extravagant sit of Love: Now to show my self a Physician of Parts. Hem! Hem!

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: Where is this Devil? Where is this cruel, inhumane, barbarous Monster?

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Here am I, no Devil, but a Man; a kind, yielding, melting Lover.
she's in a desperate taking: Hem! Hem! How she stares on me, and devours me with her Eyes.
sp.stage: The Doctor scts his Wig in order, and smiles on her.

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: What does the Villain jear and laugh at me after all; O Devil! Devil! Let me come near to thee, that I may revenge my self for all I have suffer'd.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Hold, hold, a Truce.

she's in a furious fit of Love I see; the Old Philosopher was in the right—
Prima Coitio est acerrima, The first Engagement is the sharpest. Truce, Truce, a little, and I'm for you again.
sp.stage: Lady Crossit follows him round the Stage, with her Arms stretcht out as before, and the Doctor makes the more haste to unbutton himself.

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: O Impudent Devil! Monstrous Hell-hound▪ a Rape! Help! Help!
sp.stage: Servants come in with Cudgels, and bastonade him round the Room.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Treason! Treason! Murder! Mercy! Murder! O my Crevat and Perriwig! What shall I do? My Profession's spoil'd for ever!

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: Monster! Devil! Pound him, break his Bones, beat him to a Jelly!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What all the House in an uproar! Hold there, and let me know what's the Matter amongst you; who's that Fellow undrest there?

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: O my Dear, a Monster, that would have offer'd Violence to my Virtue; would have ravish'd me, but for the Servants who came in to my assistance.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Speak, Monster of Monsters; what art thou?

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: O, Sir John, your most humble Servant,
I am a Doctor of Physick, my Name's Lorman,
Sir John, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Dr. Lorman, what, a Doctor of Physick Practising undrest; is it you, good Doctor, who would have thought it! I cou'd have sworn Butter wou'd not have melted in his Mouth, by his fine Talking!— Well, I shall alwaies suspect the worst of a fine Talking man, that can do nothing but Talk finely, for his sake.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Now I begin to see day a little, the Lady is Literally run Mad for Love, and in this mad fit, she thinks I am some Monster or other, and has treated me accordingly: But I must frame some plausible Excuse, to save my Credit and Doctoral Authority, if the aking of my Bones, will permit me to Harangue.

Honour'd, Sir, I imagine you are not a little surpris'd, as also, your much Honour'd and Virtuous good Lady; who by this time, I dare aver, is return'd to her good Senses again, to behold a Person of my Coat at this present in disorder: But when you shall have understood the Reasons I had to put in practice this Mysterious Operation; I promise my self, you will not only hold me guiltless of any ill designs, but also applaud my Conduct and Physical way of Proceeding in a Matter of so weighty Consequence.

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: What, is the Villain going to discover all? What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Perceiving at my first Entrance. But first let me beg the favour of perusing my Habiliments again.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: By all means, pray let the Dr. peruse his Habiliments.
Doctor

Perceiving at my first Entrance, as I was saying, that your very honour'd and vertuous good Lady's indisposition— Sir John, may I beg the favour you wou'd be pleas'd to order one of your Attendants to restore my Periwig to its former decorum.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: By all means, Doctor; who's there? give the Doctor's Wig to my Valet to revive it a little.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Perceiving at my first entrance, as I was saying, that—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I pray dispatch, for my Wife's indispos'd, and wants repose.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Now I am a Doctor of Physick again, and can harangue.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: How the Villain holds me in suspence.
O, Grace, I am ruin'd for ever, if he produces the Letter I sent him.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Never fear, Madam, let him go on, I warrant we have Cudgel'd him into discretion.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Hem, hem, perceiving at my first entrance—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: He's perceiving at his sirst entrance again; what did you perceive at your first Entrance?

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: That your honour'd and good Lady's indisposition had troubl'd and diverted the right course of her senses, which I soon discover'd by a disorderly stare, or rowling of her eyes; it immediately came into my head, to restore your Lady's health, by playing a piece of ingenious Extravagance; upon which, incontinently I fell to undressing and dismantling my self—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes, incontinently indeed, Doctor!

sp.speaker: Dr. Lor.
sp.p: And threatned to assault your Virtuous Lady by way of a Rape; but as I hope to receive a Fee to day, without any sinister intention, Sir John, your good Lady's natural inclination to Vertue, restor'd her to her right senses again; caus'd chiefly by the fright with which I struck her good Ladyship, for I had put on a look as fierce as that of a Centaur.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That is to say, of a Horse Doctor, by way of Parenthesis only.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: Sir John, I am your most humble Servant; but I am a Member of the Reverend Colledge.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There's a Footman without, who enquires for Dr. Lorman, says he comes from my Lady Lackit, who lies dangerously ill, and desires the Doctor would come to her immediately.

sp.speaker: Dr. Lorm.
sp.p: She's a very impertinent Lady, I am not in a Condition of serving her at present, but I'll make use of this pretence to go home, and apply Salves and Ointments to my back and sides.

Sir John, I am heartily sorry I am interrupted by the Request of this Lady, for my Personal Appearance to relieve her, and that I have not leisure to dilate on this wonderful Cure I have wrought to day morning on your very Virtuous, and much honour'd Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Crossit.
sp.p: I can assure you, Doctor, I won'd rather have chosen to have remain'd indispos'd, than to be Cur'd 〈◊〉 such an undecent and 〈◊〉 way, it has put me in such a fright.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Admirably well Counterfeited, Madam.

sp.speaker: D. Lorman.
sp.p: There is a virtuous Wife for you; Sir John, you are very happy in a virtuous Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 seem to be sorry for his being beaten to satisfie my Husband (to D. Lorman) I am infinitely concern'd, Doctor, that you have receiv'd so 〈◊〉 a Recompence for the great service you have done me to day. My Servants beat you like a very Stock-Fish.

sp.speaker: D. Lorm.
sp.p: Dear Madam, never trouble your self for that, the Credit I shall gain in the World for this Operation, will make me sufficient amends. I aim at Fame— Madam, Hercules gain'd Heaven by his Club; and I mount up to the top of Fame and Heaven of Reputation, by means of the Cudgel, like a second Hercules— But I must take my leave of you now, Sir John, to wait on this Patient, who expects me; she is a Lady of Quality, and must be serv'd punctually.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You have more need to look after your self, Doctor; you must of necessity have receiv'd some damage in your outward Man.

sp.speaker: D. Lorm.
sp.p: Nothing at all, Sir John, a trifle, a Rib or two of lesser note broken, or so, nothing else, on my word, a meer Trifle, Sir John, and Madam, your most humble Servant.
sp.stage: Sir John offers him a Fee.

sp.speaker: D. Lorm.
sp.p: Sir John, I wonder you'l put your self to this trouble, suspend your Favours 'till I have done your Lady some further service.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But for the beating, Doctor, you must accept it indeed.

sp.speaker: D. Lorm.
sp.p: You are so obliging, Sir John! well, I'le protest I'le have nothing from you, for my next Visit. Sir John, and sweet Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So he said the very last time he was here; so far by the help of my own Wit, and Grace's assistance, I have carried it victoriously, not only satisfied my self on the Body of him that might have made me a Cuckold, but also reveng'd my self bodily on my Wife, that would have made me a Cuckold.
Come Sweet heart, how does your Face?

sp.speaker: La. Cros.
sp.p: O Sir John, so torn and scratcht.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Scratching is an Appendix to Caterwauling.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Doctor, Madam, was justly beaten for his wonderful Cure, but he was to have cur'd you another way.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You may understand without my telling you.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: What should I understand?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your own Folly.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: Ah me.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
No more, you must understand me now. The Leter and Shirts
〈◊〉: I have 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, your 〈◊〉 would 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 you than Excuses, or seeming 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: Oh Sir John, Can you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'le try.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: By all my hopes of good, I'le never more injure you in a Thought.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Tis well, rise and compose your self, for we are invited by Landy, to his Daughter's Wedding, they are ready to 〈◊〉 from Church.

sp.speaker: L. Cros.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you will not carry me in this Condition.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, but I will, or else worse Interpretation may be made of it; no more words, I must be obey'd in this; I have hid your shame and mine: Henceforth, be your own Doctor, and prescribe your self a Constant use of Virtue.

lg.l: For that Receipt ne're fail'd of doing good,
And Cures the looser Feavers of the blood.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: By this time Lucy has her Wishes, and I have mine; if the Plot should be discover'd, I hope Bellville has too much mettle to lose his Mistress; the Knight will look as blank as a Cut-Purse, that finds no Money in the place he searcht for— No matter, 'tis not the first Game he has lost, and Phill will stand him another very good Chace.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Lurch and his Wife.

sp.speaker: O Mr.
sp.p: Lurch, you are welcome, heartily welcome, and your fair Partner too; they are coming, Mr. Lurch, with your Letters about 'em.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: I wish they may prove Easie to all, especially to fair Mrs. Lucy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lurch.
sp.p: She deserves all Happiness.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I thank you both.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John Crossit and his Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir John,
sp.p: Welcome good Sir John, and your good Lady too, what is not your Lady well?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She has got an unhappy fall, Mr. Landy, and very much hurt her Face, but her respect to you and Mrs. Lucy, forc'd her to come, notwithstanding her unfit Condition.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: In Troth, Madam, I am very much oblig'd to you, the new Married People, I believe, are near upon returning.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mr. Bellville will be a happy man.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: None, Sir, my Daughter is to be a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How, a Lady?

sp.speaker: Mr. Lurch.
sp.p: This is very strange.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Sir, a Northern Knight, one Sir Timothy Shallow, has out-bid Mr. Bellville by a Thousand a Year.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I wish Mr. Landy that you are not brib'd to make your Daughter unhappy.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I have known many, Sir John, very unhappy by being too Poor, but never any by being too Rich.
Harke—
I hear 'em coming.

div.stage: Enter ●…well like Hymen, going before; Sir Timothy and his Lady, and Bellville with his.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: What's here, a Mask?

lg.l: I now represent Hymen, Signior Landy,
My Deputy has done as well as can be;
Has made their Tongues tie knots to such a wonder,
That their own Teeth, tho' Bones, can't knaw asunder:
And now we are for jollity preparing,
Which all ('till deep Night calls) shall have a share in.
Then we must leave the Lovers to their own share,
To end their Kind Disputes in Civil-Warfare;
Where the least Mercy the most Love expresses,
And he most gentle proves, that most oppresses.
While the Fair Sufferer Languishing cries sie on't,
The God of Love's the only pleasing Tyrant;
Advance, Sir Tim, and with a dutiful guessing,
Find out your Daddy quickly, and ask Blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What, Madam, not down upon your Maribones; come, off with your trumpery— how— what have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this? woe's me, what have I got?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: An Obedient Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, in geud faith, hold a blow, Ise not be chous'd so.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Where's my Daughter, I am abus'd, where's my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here, Sir, with her Husband, and beg your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Hey day, what means all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, by the Mass, Mrs. Lucy is my Wife, and no other, and Ise seize my own Chattel where I find her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You must seize this first.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a God's name, must one sight for his Wife? Father Landy, I pray let us send for Mr. Scrible, and clap Actions on 'em for Cheats and Robbers.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: 'Troth, Sir Timothy, Law-Suits are dangerous Boggs to get into, we may sink faster than we can get out; besides, I fear Matters are gone too far.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Be appeas'd, Sir Timothy, what's done, can't be undone; be contented, many have done worse, you have Marry'd a handsom Woman, vertuous and good.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, none exceeds her in goodness, and good humour; I have esteem'd and lov'd her, as I would a Sister.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why, in troth, Sir Timothy, since we are both deceiv'd, the best way is to bear it patiently; and, in troth, she has always behav'd her self so well, she shall not come a Beggar to you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hope, Mr. Bellville, for my sake, will add to my Father's 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That I will, most willingly, and as largely as my dearest Lucy pleases.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: Look you there, Sir Knight, come, give her your hand; nay, never hang back, there is no other Remedy; come, come, she'll bring you a brave young Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: If it must be so, y faith Ise gang into the North as fast as four Legs will carry me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: This minute, if you please; Sir, you shall ever find me an Obedient Wife, and with true Love and Care will ever strive to please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Since I am Pounded, and no 〈◊〉 out, Ise e'en make the best of a bad Market.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I dare swear you will be pleas'd with her, when you know her better. Come, no more words, nothing now but Musick, and every Man take his Lady.

sp.speaker: Feew.
sp.p: I having none of my own, must presume to borrow another Man's.

sp.speaker: Lurch.
sp.p: Like enough, in troth.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here are Gipsies, that desire admittance.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Let 'em come in, all's free this day.

sp.speaker: 1. Gipsie.
sp.p: Bless you Masters, we'll tell your Fortunes.

lg.l: O Master! you may be happy if you will,
For 'tis a good Jack, that makes a good Gill.

sp.speaker: 2. Gipsie.
sp.p: Master, Master.
You have a great Cross thro' the Line of Life, Perhaps y'are Jealous, y'had as good trust your Wife.

sp.speaker: 3 Gipsie.
sp.p: You shall enjoy good health, and good cheer, And have a young Huntsman within the year.

sp.speaker: 4 Gipsie.
sp.p: O brave Palms, you have Mistresses plenty, And you can be Constant at once to twenty.

sp.speaker: Old Landy.
sp.p:
Come, Mr. Lurch, you cou'd Sing well in your young days, if Marriage has not crackt your Voice, let's hear the Dialogue between
you, and your Wife; it may be a means to make a thorough Reconciliation.

lg.l: WHy so Coy, and so Strange?
Does your Kindness decline?
Your Love find a Change,
Or do you doubt mine?
When inconstant Men grow,
We can quickly discern,
And our Sex you all know,
Are apt Scholars to Learn.
I watch'd how your Eyes on Phillis wero glancing,
Crown'd with a Garland of Roses for Dancing:
When the Pedlar came, you gave her a Lace,
And a fine gaudy string for her Needle-Case.
You remember, it may be,
When you were May-Lady,
The nimble Thyrsis so Caper d and Chanted,
You gave him a Ribband so long that it flaunted
And wav'd in the air; when the brisk youth then try'd
For a Kiss, you simper'd, and faintly deny'd:
And blushing; you only cry'd fie, forbear,
You're such another; nay, pish, I swear
There was ne'er in the World such rudeness as this;
Yet gently contriv'd he shou'd ravish a Kiss.

p.hi: Now prithec let's leave this impertinent struggle,

sp.speaker: She.
sp.p: For Men will be false,

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: And Women will juggle.

lg.l: Then let us be easie by freedom hereafter,
For Jealousie never yet mended the Matter.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: What's past, we'll forget,

p.hi: But take surest Advice of present Desire.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Now to such poor Cheer as I have provided for you;
Joys Crown you all, every one here's my Guest, 〈◊〉 all are welcome to a Miser's Feast.
